alternatives.transcript: good morning welcome to Kennedy and it is midweek Wednesday morning it is mid June June the 15th since mid Norm here hi I'm Nancy Wilson on the program this half hour we'll take a look at this week's Landmark Court decision in the United States which says a tobacco company is partially responsible for the death of a smoker will find out what the prospects are for similar lawsuits being launched here in Canada that's all coming up but first here's terilyn with the morning news

this week a US Federal jury found that a cigarette company was partly responsible for the death of a smoker Rose chip alone was 58 when she died of lung cancer in 1984 her husband was awarded a hundred four hundred thousand dollars and legal experts are now suggesting the Court's decision could open the floodgates for similar suits in Canada and the United States joining us from New York is Steven Parish one of the defense attorneys for to the tobacco companies also in New York Richard Dana read

chairman of the tobacco products liability project with us an Ottawa David's winner who is with the non-smokers Rights Association and joining us in Toronto Ron heart he lost a brother and a father to lung cancer and is now the executive director of the group relatives of the dead and dying smokers mr. dainard you've studied tobacco liability cases for several years now what makes this case unique we won and beyond that well there have been tremendous

developments in the case three in particular the first was the development of the release of over 300 exhibits which had been developed by the plaintiffs by pulling them with the plaintiffs did ensure it is they went through over a million pages of documents that the

this tree had developed in its own files and they pulled out the 300 most damaging most revealing exhibits and the introduce them in the trial and we at the tobacco products liability project in Boston made them available about two months ago to attorneys not only in the United States but in Canada and throughout the world and these exhibits are going to form the basis of lawsuit

throughout the world the second thing that happened was that judge sarakin the judge in the case at the end of the plaintiffs case the defendant said is not enough evidence here to go to the jury just end the case now the judge looked at the plaintiffs evidence and he said a lot of things about it he's which he really summarized by saying that the jury could find in the end they didn't but that they could find from this and other juries presumably can't find that the defendants engaged in a conspiracy that was vast

and its scope devious in his purpose and devastating and was consequently the third thing of course is the very first verdict for a plaintiff ever in a tobacco liability canister Parish the plaintiff say they won but I gather the tobacco companies the people you represent claim you one as well right what you're exactly right and I think Professor de Nardi and I agree at least on this that what we had in this case was an attempt by the plaintiff to prove the existence of a conspiracy to miss

the American public to conceal facts from the American public and what the plaintiff in this case did was go through over a hundred or over a million pages of documents pick out portions of certain documents that they wanted to show the jury the jury concluded unanimously there was no conspiracy there was no concealment there was no fraud there was no misrepresentation so I'm thrilled with that result but still after Parish right

her up you for the first time ever a tobacco company was found partially responsible for the death of a smoker the tobacco company had to pay 400 thousand dollars how can you look at that and say we won well I here's how I say we want first of all the finding against Liggett for the four hundred thousand dollars I think will be overturned on appeal the finding had nothing to do with these internal documents of Professor Denard and others have bragged about over the months it related

to a few old ads by Liggett & Myers as to whether or not there was a contract between mrs. chip alone and Liggett & Myers the jury found that there was a contract between mrs. chip alone and Liggett they found that mrs. chip alone had not been damaged as a result of that contract but for some reason they decided that mr. chip alone should get damages I think that result will be overturned on appeal and and again the important thing is that the result on this breach of warranty or

contract claim had nothing to do with these documents that so much has been made to do about okay mr. Sweeney this is of course a very complicated case with all kinds of legal innuendo inside variations putting that aside and just looking at the broad brushstrokes what's the significance of this case for Canada well I think what we're going to see is is cases in Canada I think from almost a psychological standpoint the mere fact that we now know that the tobacco industry can be

beaten they were beaten they are vegan cleanly in the stock market indicated yesterday that they know that back when just be was beaten because tobacco stocks fell Philip Morris is stock market value decreased by some quarter of a billion dollars yesterday while the rest of the stocks are going up I think what we're going to see in Canada is the the fact that under our law we have some advantages that they don't have in the states some of the technical arguments that have worked for the tobacco industry in the United States will not be able to work under Canadian law I think that as a

result of that we certainly have a very real possibility of seeing breakthroughs here that perhaps go beyond what we're now seeing in the United States yet there has never been a case in Canada where anyone has tried to sue Tobacco Company Harlan no there are no cases that have been filed so far which I think is the Canadian mentality waiting and seeing what the u.s. manages get done in their courts but I think we would be surprised if three months from now you could say the same thing I think there are cases coming mr. Rai your father died of lung cancer your brother died of lung

answer you your family believe that tobacco was the caused the death of correct yes that's right did it ever occur to you or what did the current you now that maybe you can go after the tobacco company and lay claim well that's certainly is a possibility after all since 1964 at least with the publication of the surgeon general's first report at least by that time the tobacco industry in Canada had a responsibility to say that tobacco

Alex could have disastrous results they haven't done that they haven't told people Of The Addictive nature of the products they haven't told people the fact that it is inherently dangerous that it can't be used safely the magnitude of the risk in using tobacco products simply has been ignored by the industry and yet that's their legal responsibilities but excuse me can I just make one point in response to that a big issue in our case was the addictive

quality of cigarette smoking if any the 1987 surgeon general's report was read to the jury at the close of the plaintiffs case and the jury in our case clearly decided that mrs. chip alone was not addicted and they clearly decided that this was a woman who had heard that cigarette smoking can be risky and that she enjoyed smoking and that she made a free decision to smoke and that was a key part of the jury's finding let me make a couple of points to As Long As mr. Parrish

he put in his go-ahead thoughts on the subject the first of all the what mr. Parrish left out in his description of what the jury found is that the jury also found that the cigarette company in this case the manufacturer of the cigarettes that Rose trip alone smoke before 1966 had an obligation to warn her about the dangers of smoking the obligation began we don't know when but the testimony in the case suggests that they had enough information by the late

30s or early 1940s at the latest to have warned all of their consumers and potential consumers that cigarette smoking may very well cause lung cancer and that this matured later on into an obligation to warn them well before the surgeon general's report that it did cause lung cancer okay mr. after they have refused to give that information to the public in fact they've misled people it's going to make it easier to bring cases is going to make it easier to get Awards against that industry we start to blame in effect the pushers instead of the victims mr. that's really a pulse round it's sort of like telling somebody hanging on a parrot that that they should jump the jury was prohibited from considering all of the evidence of the defendants fraud and conspiracy after 1966 as a result of a peculiar interpretation of the intent of the United States Congress in passing cigarette labeling acts there is no similar act in Congress and that means in Canada and that means that in Canada you're going to be able to have juries view the entire

our conspiracy the entire behavior of the tobacco industry from the beginning from the 1940s up through the date of the trial actually started afraid we have run out of time thank you so much obviously the debate will continue we'll be right back stay tuned
